This list is incomplete; you can help by expanding it.
First-made LOVE sculpture, at Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, Indiana
In New York City, New York
In JFK Plaza, Philadelphia with Museum of Art
At the Scottsdale, Arizona Civic Center


This is a list of the many versions of Robert Indiana's Love sculpture that exist worldwide (1969–1999). The original Pop Art image was created for print media in the 1960s. The first rendering of it in sculpture was made in 1970. Sculptural versions now appear in urban centers around the globe. Variants employ the Hebrew, Chinese,[citation needed] Italian and Spanish languages as well as the original English language.

Contents

  • 1 Versions of Love in the United States
  • 2 Versions of Love in Canada
  • 3 Versions of Love in Europe
  • 4 Versions of Love in Asia
  • 5 Versions of Love in South America
  • 6 Versions of Love in other languages
  • 7 References

Versions of Love in the United States[edit]

  • Wichita State University campus in Wichita, Kansas
  • Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, Indiana – The original sculpture version
  • Sixth Avenue, on the southeast corner of West 55th Street in New York City, New York
  • E.W. Fairchild-Martindale Library, Lehigh University Asa Packer Campus in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania
  • Pratt Institute campus in Brooklyn, New York Visited in 2016, was not on display.
  • Scottsdale Civic Center in Scottsdale, Arizona
  • Love Park (John F. Kennedy Plaza) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
  • New Orleans Museum of Art's sculpture garden in New Orleans, Louisiana
  • Middlebury College campus in Middlebury, Vermont[1][2]
  • University of Pennsylvania campus in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
  • Brigham Young University Museum of Art in Provo, Utah
  • Ursinus College campus in Collegeville, Pennsylvania
  • Farnsworth Art Museum in Rockland, Maine
  • In the median of 96th Street in Bay Harbor Islands, Florida[3]
  • Art Trail outside the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Arkansas
  • McNay Art Museum in San Antonio, Texas
  • University of Oklahoma in Norman, Oklahoma
  • San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in San Francisco, California
  • Tennis court behind the abandoned Public Health Service Hospital at the Nike Missile Site SF-89L[4] in San Francisco, California[5]
  • Minneapolis Sculpture Garden in Minneapolis, Minnesota
  • Panda Restaurant Group in Rosemead, California
  • Arts Park and Arts Garden in New Castle, Indiana (Robert Indiana’s hometown)
  • Louis Campau Promenade in Downtown Grand Rapids, Michigan.
This version of Robert Indiana's Love sculpture was painted on a tennis court by artist, Erik Seidenglanz. The sculpture sits above the Nike Missile Site SF-89L behind the abandoned Public Health Service Hospital in the Presidio, San Francisco, California.

Versions of Love in Canada[edit]

  • Old Montreal in front of Lhotel 262 Saint Jacques Street West in Montreal, Quebec[6]
  • In San Francisco, California
    Outside 1445 West Georgia Street in Vancouver, British Columbia – this gallery has closed and the sculpture moved
  • Near "Central Park" development on Rymal Road, Hamilton, Ontario

Versions of Love in Europe[edit]

At Langen Foundation in Neuss-Holzheim, Germany
AMOR at exhibition in Valencia, Spain (2007)
Love in City of London
  • Plaza del Sagrado Corazón in Bilbao, Spain
  • Rossio Square (Praça do Rossio) in Lisbon, Portugal
  • Chatsworth in Derbyshire, England, as part of the Sotheby's Beyond Limits exhibition, 2008
  • Bidzina Ivanishvili[clarification needed] palace in Tbilisi, Georgia
  • Yerevan Cascade in Yerevan, Armenia
  • Bishopsgate and Wormwood Street, City of London, England (southwest corner) ––[7] temporary exhibit, May 2013 – June 2014.
  • Fondation Pierre Gianadda in Martigny, Switzerland

Versions of Love in Asia[edit]

  • Shinjuku I-Land Tower in Nishi-Shinjuku office district in Tokyo, Japan
  • In a round about in Chiba, Chiba, Japan[8]
  • Taipei 101 in Taipei, Taiwan (also inside displays Indiana's 1-0)[9]
  • Winsland Plaza (between Winsland House I & II) in Singapore[10]
  • Amorepacific Museum of Art in Yongin, South Korea (LOVE installations on site, playing on the LOVE theme)
  • Amorepacific Corporation factory (indoor) in Osan, South Korea
  • CentralWorld shopping plaza and complex in Bangkok, Thailand (in the ZEN store; destroyed by the fire during the 2010 Thai political protests)
  • Zendai Museum of Modern Art in Shanghai, China
  • World Trade Centre in Hong Kong, China (taken down)
  • Eastwood City in Quezon City, Philippines[11]
  • Love Park in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, since July 2009[12]
  • Gandaria City in Jakarta, Indonesia[13]
  • Magsaysay Avenue in Naga City, Camarines Sur, Philippines
  • Baywalk in City of Naga, Cebu, Philippines
  • Love Lock in Bandung City Hall, Bandung, Indonesia
  • Sabah Surya in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah Malaysia
  • Love sculpture in Hebrew is displayed at the Israel Museum
  • Antilia in Mumbai, India
  • In front of Christ Church in Melacca City, Malaysia

  • Love in Singapore

Versions of Love in South America[edit]

Love sculpture displayed at the Parque metropolitano El Lago in Bogotá, Colombia
  • Parque metropolitano El Lago in Bogotá, Colombia

Versions of Love in other languages[edit]

Love sculpture in Hebrew is displayed at the Israel Museum
  • An Indiana sculpture showing "amor" is displayed at the National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden in Washington, D.C.[14]
  • An Indiana sculpture showing the Italian word for love (Italian: amor) was displayed outside the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II on Piazza della Scala in Milan, Italy. This sculpture is no longer there (visited 12 May 2016).
  • An Indiana sculpture showing the Hebrew word for love (Hebrew: אהבה‎, ahava) is displayed at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem.
